Please note mistake: the end of the 1st paragraph, which reads
" perhaps even dishonoring the memory of Christians", the word "Christians" should be replace with: "Hitchens"

"Thus it should read: perhaps even dishonoring the memory of Hitchens.

Mr. Hitchens died undoubtedly an atheist. But here Mr. Douthat is raising him from the dead as virtual Christian. It's a nice job of attempting to sell Hitchens post posthumously to certain hard boiled Christians, but it would seem to be a disservice, perhaps even dishonoring the memory of Christians, who never sought such cover.

Mature, established and more liberal minded Christains have no problem with atheists, like Hitchens, who are making a good faith (no pun intended) attempt at seeking the truth. In this vein of Christianity, it is understood that each person follows a unique path to finding God. Here they need to merely point to C.S. Lewis.

The intolerant Christians (an oxymoron if there ever was one), Christians that rely more on the old testament than the new to manifest hate and intolerance, these are the ones that normally would attack Hitchens, but in the last quarter of Hitchens life, while he never came to religion, he did come to this brand of Christianities politics - most decidedly after 9/11 Hitchens found himself a conservative.

I'm incline to believe that this was a strategic move by Hitchens. Vehemently anti-religion, I'm incline to believe that though Hitchens thought all religion to be dangerous to enlightenment, he saw Islam as the religious movement that was the greatest threat to the enlightenment, and thus decided to form a political alliance with the right, including Christians on the right, in opposing fundamentalist-militant Islam.

He had his opinions, expressed more abrasively than I would have, even though I may have disagreed with the subject, more than he may have.

I am forever for freedom of expression, particularly when it is in the minority, and different and passionately challenges the norm. These views, no matter however expressed, will have to be intellectually persuasive and convincing before I'd go along with them. I'm not interested in religion, and his views weren't much different from what I have heard. That's why his atheist views didn't surprise me or interest me.

I didn't worry about his views on God and religion. There are people who don't believe in god or the same God as your own, and surprise, there are also non-Christians in the world (Jews, Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists and others).

He was a voice, contrarian, passionate and challenging that's gone -- a Believer or not, doesn't much matter to me. I didn't agree with him much, but he has point of view and I wanted to see him air it. I'll miss him.

It is a somewhat strange quirk of anti-religious bigotry to personify religion--the diverse spiritual habits of probably over 90% of the species--as the uniform behavior and process of one chimerical, all-purpose "believer." With what other group would you feel comfortable talking about what "they" are all like? How would you recognize the overlap of faith and scientific pursuits among some of histories greatest scientists/believers? Furthermore, what you call 'hidden' meanings other people might term interpretation, speculation, construction--things fundamental to the pursuit of knowledge. Interpretation, you see, is this thing that humans do when processing basically any information that enters their environment, whether scientific, literary, religious, romantic or whatever. Douthat did not, in what I read, imply that Hitch was a Christian, but rather seemed to elucidate how he was not so different. And it would take a quirk of belief not  to see that Hitchens pursued religion and belief with an absolutist frenzy rarely found save for among the most fervent of believers. May Athe bless and keep him.
"Dead at face value" fully explains the belief system of Christopher Hitchens when all is said and done.

It is a somewhat strange quirk of religion that a believer needs to grasp at 'hidden' meanings apparently as self-justification for their belief. Historically it seems that things that could not be explained were somehow the work of gods, or more recently god.
I find it not very surprising that those apparent believers, including Douthat, need to find apparently 'hidden' meaning or motives in the clearly expressed words of an avowed atheist. Perhaps their own faith is far too frail to not accept the statements of a man who is now dead at face value.

15.7 million unemployed in October 2009 6 million graduates = 21.6 million MINUS 3 million NET jobs created = 18.6 million

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports 13.3 million.

I estimate there are another 8.4 million no longer even being counted (the BLS claiming they stopped looking for work, based on a flawed CPS household survey).

We live in Seattle and have our toddler enrolled in NSCC Coop Preschool. This is a program run by the community colleges of Seattle and is an umbrella for approximately 80 separate non-profit pre-school coops. Caregivers are required to enroll as students with the college while participating in the coop. The college provides a "parent educator" that helps parents with the ins and outs of running a self contained and legal preschool while also teaching the latest in early childhood development. The college requires caregivers to comply with a clearly defined set of rules. Other than that, the coops have their own board of directors and make their own agreements. All caregivers are required to work about 10 hours a week - I'm the treasurer for our coop and handle pretty much all the legalities of the organization, and yes it's complex with a lot of red tape, but this model of pre-school has been around Seattle for decades now, and there is lots of help from the college. As for the curricula, each coop hires well qualified and enthusiastic teachers who are cutting edge in the latest early childhood development. The coop program goes on for four years - each year the child attending more days and hours while the caregivers step back and allow the children to experience more autonomy. The cost comes out to be about $500 for one half day per week for the 9 month session and rises as the children attend more days and hours. We feel fortunate. http://coops.northseattle.edu/

I agree. We are at a crossroads where we have the means to evolve humanistically but our focus had been for self satisfaction and profits. In order for true change to come about we must be bound together in a state of mutual concern and guarantee, a social contract that admits we are nothing if we are not united for the purpose of the general well being of our brothers. Only from this standpoint of internal awakening can we begin to build the society that can withstand the developmental changes that we must undergo in order to thrive together. Leaders at this point would quite probably be provocateurs of false hope intelligent enough to appease the masses by pretending to address humankind's desire for self determination. This is also a time to question the notion of the concept of leaders in general because after all leaders require followers and this is always where the deception begins. It may become absolutely necessary to  become highly educated self sustaining communities cooperating for mutual benefit without living in servitude to a leader or materialistic set of values.

This also holds true in the Arab nations where their culture has no foundation in America's ego central sense of being the example of how to run a country, for a people where civilization had its birth.

If only greater "disruption" would come about! The herd seems to be motivated as ever, the manupilation continues, just look at the Murdoch impact. Look at the impact of a crook (von Guttenberg) in Germany, as if Hitler had never been, or the crazy nationalism in Britain. The people feel more empowered and use their power to be stupid. Education is the challenge that lies ahead.

However dramatic the cumulative impact of the merger of information technology and globalsation might appear on surface level or in unleashing new forces of disruption, nonetheless, when it comes to genuine socio-economic reconstruction and creative political innovation, the twin phenomena certainly fell short of the impact, the epoch defining renaissance and enlightenment developments could produce some five to six centuries ago; for, unlike these creative humanistic impulse driven evolutions, since the twin developments of IT and globalisation were essentially ignited by technology and economic profit motives, they could create a false consciousness of liberation or a sense of individual empowerment, but never a genuine sense of community belonging or a social contract that binds the ruler and the ruled with a common thread of mutual sustenance and obligations, hence a widespread social disarray, leadership vacuum and political chaos underpinning the disruptive change across the world from Europe-America to Middle East, Asia to Africa. Under the prevailing conditions, it's futile then, to look for the leaders who, could deliver, connect with the people or have a vision of leading from the bottom up?
